DWYW

Terrapolis

Maria Arnold & Jakob Köchert

In the context of the Anthropocene, climate change and the urgency to find new ways of relating and grounding ourselves to the earth, the aim of this research project was to explore multispecies thinking, to find new ways of reading the city from this more than human perspective and to imagine a naturecultural implementation into the existing urban fabric.

Following ideas of post-humanism, and –dualism, and the new materialisms, the corresponding ontological shift invites to change the perception of the world from one full of objects and subjects, to one full of agentic beings that are inextricably connected with each other. Through opening subjectivity to the whole, the notion of care can be implemented as a new form of relational ethics.

Leaning on this new ontology and conception of ethics, a speculation gives rise to novel soil spaces on discontinued graveyard sites and the implementation of corresponding soil practices, including the composting of deceased bodies. The imagined proposal acts as a thought object to discover multispecies thinking through a typological approach. It is an attempt to find new ways of relating to nonhumans; to think a space from the soils perspective, turning it from a resource to the protagonist, connecting everything else involved.

1

It was you,
who brought me into existence.

You nurtured me,
raised me with patience and grace,
held me in your arms.

But this has come to an end.
Now your form has changed.

It is me who is holding you now.

Metamorphosis transcends all our realities.
As one body decays, another one emerges.

I can feel the soil between my fingers.
Feel your being, that persists in this living matter.
It calms me to know, that life goes on.

2

We can’t speak as we used to,
but your voice will remain present.

I will listen to it carefully in the rustling leaves;
feel your caresses on my skin, when a gentle breeze touches me;
smell your grace in the sweetness of blooming flowers;
taste your abundance in the fruits hanging from the trees;
see your merciless beauty in my everyday encounters.

You are whispering to yourself,
the same song that my senses sing.

Braided reciprocities in ongoing vibrance,
flowing through our bodies,
in the everlasting desire for connectedness.

But there was a time
I did not understand those melodies.

3

A time when I thought
I could exist separately from you;
Cutting away the living significance tying us together.
- But that was when I separated from myself.

In the recognition of our shared being,
I found the peace that I longed for.

Solitude vanished, as from now on,
you will always be on my side.
And I will take care of you,
As you have taken care of me.

A relationship of mutuality,
is what we are.
It is through this relation,
that I will know what to do.

4

To acknowledge this,
is to return to what I truly am.

I am now certain,
there is no end.
Because being with you,
it is always now.

One day my body will die
and pass on what it has borrowed.
But I will not vanish.

I will always be you,
as you always were me.

5

The future of contemporary graveyards is uncertain. As the demand for religious burials decreases, their gradual discontinuation leaves many of them in a potential state of transformation. Discussions about their future mainly turn around the reuse as recreational parks or as building plots for residential housing. Through a multispecies lens, other potentials emerge worth considering. In the face of ecological crisis, our contemporary burial and mourning culture seem worth to be reconsidered.

Looking at current burial procedures by ecological means, unveils their problematic condition. Soils are polluted with concrete tombs, steel coffins and lacquer finishes. Cremation emits substantial amounts of carbon dioxide into the atmosphere and requires huge quantities of energy.

Life and death are necessary partners in the ecological cycle of ongoingness. Rethinking our burial practice through a materialistic lens leads to a proposition that returns our bodies to the very foundation of all life cycles: The composting of human and non human deceased bodies into fertile soil and its reintegration into productive cycles, providing nourishment, for living human and non human bodies. The proposal reconfigures the graveyard typology:

6

The convergence of compost burial grounds and permacultural gardening, gives rise to a space for soil-centred practices.

The dissolution of individual graves into a shared and maintained garden, grows out of the alignment with a horizontal and relational ontology of all living beings. Human and non human bodies become entangled in recomposed matter, to form the collective ground of new life. A collective ground for the implementation of a new cosmology.

This invites to reimagine and extend our ways of mourning: Honouring the dead can manifest in care for the living. Decay can be valued as the foundation of new beginnings. Grief for the loss can be eased through gratitude for the emerging.

At the heart of those everyday doings lies the incentive to sup- port the growth and healing of existing urban ecosystems and our connection to them, increasing their inherent resilience, biodiversity and productivity. It is a practice that foregrounds the importance of care, maintenance and repair to the very material sustaining of the world.

Valuing practice-sharing, teaching and community building, Terrapolis could be enriched with pedagogic facilities in symbiosis with the space:

7

Daycare centers and schools to foster multispecies, decolonized, posthuman education models and soil research and permaculture training facilities to expand the practice further into society.

It is particularly in the uneventful, everyday doings, that transformation can start to take shape; that new ways of becoming-with each other can be brought into existence.

To look closely at soil, and find ways to familiarize with it, rediscovering its condition as living matter coexisting with us, has the potential to give us a necessary grounding and agency need- ed in times of connection loss and crisis.

This new kind of typology could be imagined as the nurturing ground for an emerging soil and earth-bound community, where scientific knowledge converges with social activism and transversal thinking. Turning humans from soil-consumers into soil community members, it is an attempt to approach multispecies thinking through a systematic reconfiguration.

What if we only had to look once again closely, to find ourselves?
